wikipedia_page.main:
2nd Lieutenant Leonard James Moon (9 February 1878 – 23 November 1916) was a cricketer  and footballer who played first-class cricket for Cambridge University from 1897 to 1900 and Middlesex County Cricket Club from 1899 to 1909. He also played four Test matches for England against South Africa in 1905-06. He also played for Fulham as a centre forward throughout 1897.
Moon was educated at Westminster School and Pembroke College, Cambridge. After university he became a schoolmaster.
He died of wounds suffered while fighting near Salonica in Greece, as a lieutenant with the Devon Regiment in the First World War. He is buried in Karasouli Military Cemetery (grave A189).His brother, Billy Moon, was also a cricketer and represented England at football.

link_mentions.page: Marylebone Cricket Club cricket team in New Zealand in 1906–07
response: Several notable amateurs were asked to tour but were unable to set aside the necessary six months to do so. They included Lord Hawke, Kenneth Hutchings, Reggie Spooner, H. D. G. Leveson Gower, Leonard Moon, Frederick Fane, Neville Knox and Henry Martyn. The Auckland Star's London correspondent wrote: "On the whole, the team does not appeal to me as being particularly formidable, and I fancy the best New Zealand teams will prove quite equal to lowering the visitors' colours."

*Second Lieutenant Leonard Moon died his wounds on 23 November 1916, near Karasouli in Salonica, Greece while fighting with the Devon Regiment.  He scored 7 first-class hundreds while playing for Cambridge University from 1897 to 1900 and Middlesex from 1899 to 1909. He played four Tests for England against South Africa in 1905–06.

William Robert Moon (7 June 1868 – 9 January 1943) was an English association football goalkeeper and a member of the England national football team. He also played first-class cricket with Middlesex. His brother Leonard Moon was a Test cricketer.

response: * Leonard Moon (1905–1909) : L. J. Moon (Middlesex). Tours: North America (1905); South Africa (1905/06).
